channel.title: Anybody else done this?
channel.description:
I basically wanted to see how stable the server was.
[img]http://desmond.imageshack.us/Himg138/scaled.php?server=138&filename=testbx.png&res=landing[/img]
This was done on localhost and the 'bots' didn't do any other actions than login, so it's not accurate at all, but when I did the same with RSCD v.25 I could barely get to 500 before it crashed.
The application I made for testing, logs in really really fast. It took about 2-3 seconds to get to 2000.

item.title: Anybody else done this?
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

[quote=“Kryptix, post:25, topic:443757”]K guys, done a bit of stress testing tonight, I think I have the most stable sauce but no point testing the player updating.

[code]/*

  • RSCDaemon Development
  • Stress Testing Max Online Count
  • No networking involved obviously, that’s pointless.
    */

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class Test {
public static void main(String[] args){
List players = new ArrayList();

	for (int i = 0; i < 2000; i++)
		players.add("Player " + i);
	
	System.out.println("RSCD: There is currently " + players.size() + " players online!");
}

}[/code]

Output:

RSCD: There is currently 2000 players online!

Can anyone beat that? Cus I think I’m hitting the limits. Might need 2 worlds.[/quote]

You forgot the password field, no wonder you can only get 2k online…

Read full topic

item.title: Anybody else done this?
item.dc:creator: @yong_min yong min
item.description:
@yong_min wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:26, topic:443757”]Different things should be tested differently. There is a difference between testing networking (which nobody has done correctly in this thread … so far) and stress testing the server to find potential bottlenecks.

Has anyone bothered to calculate the maximum network load that 2000 players require for a single game tick?

Edit : oh and kryppledcock…did zilent make that for yous?[/quote]

Of course Zilent wrote it. Silly question!

Read full topic

item.title: Anybody else done this?
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

Instead of creating 2000 connections on one client… create the 2000 characters server sided. In this stability test, are we testing the stability of the server or the stability of the networking?

We’re testing everything.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Kryptix Kryptix
item.description:
@Kryptix wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

Instead of creating 2000 connections on one client… create the 2000 characters server sided. In this stability test, are we testing the stability of the server or the stability of the networking?

Both? It’s not a very accurate test if it’s not sending updates from/to 2,000 players and merely just leaving them there…

item.title: Anybody else done this?
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

I kinda upgraded the ‘StabilityTester’ to make a new connection per login and spam on chat. I managed to get 1500 online before the StabilityTester crashed, the server’s latency went to about 200ms. And again, note that this is done on localhost.

Read full topic

item.title: Anybody else done this?
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“Chuck testa, post:6, topic:443757”][quote author=-Nothing link=topic=546435.msg4006087#msg4006087 date=1338655526]

If all they do is log in, then why don’t their connections get dropped?

They do. But I have so much firepower. That picture is taken about 5 seconds after I started this twice:

[code]package org.moparscape.msc.client;

import java.util.List;
import java.util.Random;

public class StabilityTester extends GameAppletMiddleMan {

private static Random rand = new Random();
/**
 * returns a random number within the given bounds
 */
public static int random(int low, int high) {
	return low + rand.nextInt(high - low + 1);
}
public static void main(String[] args) {
	for(int i=0;i<1500;i++) {
		new StabilityTester();
	}
}
private boolean running;
public StabilityTester() {
	running = true;
	pingThread().start();
	new Thread(new Runnable() {
		public void run() {
			while (running) {
				for(int i = 0; i < 2000;i++) {
					connect("Player" + random(0, 500000), "password", false);
					logged = true;
				}
				try {
					Thread.sleep(100);
				} catch (InterruptedException e) {
					// TODO Auto-generated catch block
					e.printStackTrace();
				}
			}
		}
	}).start();
}
private boolean logged;
public Thread pingThread() {
	Thread thread = new Thread(new Runnable() {
		public void run() {
			while (running) {
				if(logged)
					sendPingPacket();
				
				try {
					Thread.sleep(50);
				} catch (InterruptedException e) {
					// TODO Auto-generated catch block
					e.printStackTrace();
				}
			}
		}
	});
	return thread;
}

}
[/code]

I tried to add ping, but it didnt seem to work, and it doesn’t matter since I got what I wanted.
[/quote]
By looking what you are doing there with your “StabilityTester” you create a thread to run the 2000 logins but each login is not threaded so the next login will be destroyed right after because of the data being replaced with the new login what surely means the old connection has died somewhere what infacts means your stability test is incorrect. and all you have is 2000+ connections but really not 2000+ active bot logins.

In short. There is one connection not 2000+ connections what really means your test is false and shit if you want to do it propley you have to thread each connection to the game and keep it processing like that otherwise your test is worthless.[/quote]

Logging in 2000 times in quick succession like that actually might be a good way to stress test a server since it’s a fairly good impulse.

Read full topic

For some reason the bots just logout within about 10 seconds after they have logged, even though they talk/send ping.
[/quote]Does that only happen with the bots?

Yes.[/quote]Where in the code is it sending a ping packet?

Also, you can get a stack trace when the connection is being closed to see why.

item.title: Anybody else done this?
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

i dont have it anymore, but its not hard to do

edit: i did find this

package melster;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.util.Random;

import network.SocketConnector;
import network.StreamClass;
import util.Config;
import util.PacketID;
import encryption.DataConversions;
import encryption.DataEncryption;
import encryption.DataOperations;

public final class Bot extends SocketConnector implements Runnable {

	public final String username, password;
	public int loginResponse = -2;
	public StreamClass streamClass;
	public Random ran = new Random();

	private final String[] WORDS = { "fuck", "bastard", "lesbian", "prostitut",
			"spastic", "vagina", "retard", "arsehole", "asshole", "tosser",
			"homosex", "hetrosex", "hitler", "urinate", "wank", "naked", "fag",
			"niga", "nige", "gay", "rape", "cock", "homo", "twat", "arse",
			"crap", "poo", "shit", "lesbo", "phuck", "bitch", "penis", "whore",
			"bisex", "sperm", "rapist", "shag", "slag", "slut", "clit", "cunt",
			"piss", "nazi", "urine" };
	
	private final String[] COLORS = { "@ran@", "@bla@", "@gre@",
			"@gr1@", "@gr2@", "@gr3@", "@cya@", "@mag@", "@whi@", "@blu@",
			"@dre@", "@ora@", "@or1@", "@or2@", "@or3@", "@lre@", "@red@" };

	protected final void login(String user, String pass) {
		try {
			user = DataOperations.addCharacters(user, 20);
			pass = DataOperations.addCharacters(pass, 20);

			streamClass = new StreamClass(makeSocket(Config.SERVER_IP, Config.SERVER_PORT), this);
			streamClass.maxPacketReadCount = 1000;
			long l = DataOperations.stringLength12ToLong(user);
			streamClass.createPacket(PacketID.SESSION_REQUEST_PACKET);
			streamClass.addByte((int) (l >> 16 & 31L));
			streamClass.addString(this.getClass().getName().toUpperCase());
			streamClass.finalisePacket();
			long sessionID = streamClass.read8ByteLong();

			int sessionRotationKeys[] = new int[4];
			sessionRotationKeys[0] = (int) (Math.random() * 99999999D);
			sessionRotationKeys[1] = (int) (Math.random() * 99999999D);
			sessionRotationKeys[2] = (int) (sessionID >> 32);
			sessionRotationKeys[3] = (int) sessionID;
			DataEncryption dataEncryption = new DataEncryption(new byte[500]);
			dataEncryption.offset = 0;
			dataEncryption.add4ByteInt(sessionRotationKeys[0]);
			dataEncryption.add4ByteInt(sessionRotationKeys[1]);
			dataEncryption.add4ByteInt(sessionRotationKeys[2]);
			dataEncryption.add4ByteInt(sessionRotationKeys[3]);
			dataEncryption.add4ByteInt(0);
			dataEncryption.addString(user);
			dataEncryption.addString(pass);
			dataEncryption.encryptPacketWithKeys(Config.KEY, Config.MODULUS);
			streamClass.createPacket(0);
			streamClass.addByte(0);
			streamClass.add2ByteInt(Config.CLIENT_VERSION);
			streamClass.addBytes(dataEncryption.packet, 0, dataEncryption.offset);
			streamClass.finalisePacket();
			loginResponse = streamClass.readInputStream();
			
			if (loginResponse == -1 || loginResponse == 5) {
				login(this.username, this.password);
				return;
			}
			return;
		} catch (Exception e) {
			try {
				Thread.sleep(5000L);
			} catch (Exception e1) {
				login(this.username, this.password);
			}
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
	}

	public Bot(String user, String pass) {
		this.username = user;
		this.password = pass;
	}

	public void run() {
		try {
			this.streamClass = new StreamClass(makeSocket(Config.SERVER_IP, Config.SERVER_PORT), this);
		} catch (IOException e) {
			e.printStackTrace();
		}

		login(username, password);

		if (loginResponse == 0) {
			sendPackets();
		}
	}

	public void sendPackets() {
		boolean running = true;
		dropItem(0);
		while (running) {
			sendChatMessage();
			sendSayCommand();
			try {
				Thread.sleep(1000l);
			} catch (InterruptedException e) {
				e.printStackTrace();
			}
		}
	}

	public void dropItem(int slot) {
		this.streamClass.createPacket(PacketID.DROP_INV_ITEM_PACKET);
		this.streamClass.add2ByteInt(slot);
		this.streamClass.formatPacket();
	}

	public void sendWalkPacket() {
		this.streamClass.createPacket(PacketID.WALK_PACKET);
		try {
			this.streamClass.finalisePacket();
		} catch (IOException e) {
			this.streamClass.formatPacket();
		}
	}

	public void sendChatMessage() {
		int word = ran.nextInt(WORDS.length), color = ran.nextInt(COLORS.length);
		streamClass.createPacket(PacketID.CHAT_PACKET);
		byte[] chatMessage = DataConversions.stringToByteArray(new StringBuilder().append(COLORS[color]).append(WORDS[word]).toString());
		streamClass.addBytes(chatMessage, 0, chatMessage.length);
		try {
			this.streamClass.finalisePacket();
		} catch (IOException e) {
			this.streamClass.formatPacket();
		}
	}
	
	public void sendSayCommand() {
		int word = ran.nextInt(WORDS.length), color = ran.nextInt(COLORS.length);
		streamClass.createPacket(PacketID.COMMAND_PACKET);
		streamClass.addString(new StringBuilder().append("say ").append(COLORS[color]).append(WORDS[word]).toString());
		streamClass.formatPacket();
	}

}

Read full topic

item.title: Anybody else done this?
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

Yeah k. I already knew that it wasn’t accurate at all, but thanks for the info.

EDIT: Actually, doesn’t it make the connection when it logs in? and I ran 1500 threads. I deleted for(int i = 0; i < 2000;i++) { from the thread and got same results with running 2500 threads.

Read full topic
